lesson.title: Types of Quadrilaterals
lesson.body:
"Quad" means "four" and "lateral" means "line." A quadrilateral is literally a shape with four sides (lines) and four angles that add to 360 degrees.
 Concave Quadrilaterals: Has one interior angle larger than 180 degrees.
 Convex Quadrilaterals: All angles are less than 180 degrees.
 Trapezoid: A quadrilateral with exactly 2 sides parallel to each other.
 Parallelogram: A quadrilateral with 2 pairs of parallel sides.
 Rectangle: A parallelogram with 4 right angles.
 Rhombus: A parallelogram where all 4 sides are equivalent.
 Square: A rectangular rhombus. In other words, a parallelogram with 4 right angles are 4 equivalent sides.

lesson.title: Quadrilateral Proofs and Angles
lesson.body:
Adjacent angles of a parallelogram are supplementary: Their sum equals 180.
 Opposite angles of a parallelogram are equivalent.
 The angles of bases of an isosceles triangle are equal.
 Area of a parallelogram is base x the bisecting height: A = bh.
